quotes.topic_title: Planning conservatively with milestone-based unlocks
quotes.text: when you have limited visibility, you have to plan in the most conservative way.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A clear rule-of-thumb for planning under uncertainty: default to conservative assumptions when visibility is low.

quotes.topic_title: Planning conservatively with milestone-based unlocks
quotes.text: you don't want to be unreasonably conservative because you don't want to be floundering from like, oh, we're screwed to everything's better, to we're screwed, everything's better.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Warns against overcorrecting into pessimism, which can create destabilizing strategic whiplash.

quotes.topic_title: Planning conservatively with milestone-based unlocks
quotes.text: setting up a really conservative plan and then having milestones, short term milestones that unlock the ability to lean into growth and spend based on hitting those targets.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A milestone-based “unlock” framework that ties incremental spend and growth bets to proven performance.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In this episode, we focus on what founders should change and how they do sales during this market downturn, including how you should approach sales quotas, how you should rethink the way you do comp plans for salespeople, how you do forecasting, also why you should refocus on retention and your existing customers, how to improve your sales technique in general no matter what role you're in.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical checklist of the core levers founders can adjust in a downturn: quotas, comp, forecasting, retention, and technique.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: As you'll hear in this episode, he has closed some incredible deals, including a wild story about cold emailing Sheryl Sandberg at Facebook and what that led to.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example that signals the episode will include real-world, high-leverage outbound tactics and lessons from them.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Sahil is the CEO and founder of Bravado, which has built the world's largest online sales community of over 300,000 salespeople, and they're now building SaaS products for salespeople.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes Sahil’s scale of exposure to sales patterns and benchmarks via a 300,000-person community—useful for grounding advice in broad experience.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, based on our data, about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: Quantifies how fragile onboarding is—one failure can drive meaningful churn, making onboarding reliability a top retention lever.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've consistently seen that improving onboarding is one of the highest leverage opportunities for both signup conversion and increasing longterm retention.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical prioritization heuristic: treat onboarding improvements as a high-ROI growth and retention initiative.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Getting people to your aha moment more quickly and reliably is so incredibly important.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear product-growth framework: optimize onboarding around time-to-value (“aha moment”) and consistency.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With one API, your team can add over 150 HR, ATS, accounting, ticketing and CRM integrations right into your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete scale example that reframes integrations as a leverage point—one abstraction can unlock broad platform coverage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can get your first integration into production in a matter of days and save countless weeks building custom integrations, letting you get back to building your core product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable build-vs-buy guidance: reduce integration drag to protect product velocity and focus on core differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Sahil’s sales career and Bravado overview
quotes.text: We didn't call it sales, right? We called it turning out the votes or street teamwork or field ops or phone banking, but it was sales.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Reframes “sales” as a universal skill (persuasion + outreach + objection handling) that applies beyond traditional business contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Sahil’s sales career and Bravado overview
quotes.text: So I've been in some sort of a role where my primary responsibility was to cold call, send emails, have conversations, objection handle, and try to get someone to sign a contract for my entire career.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable breakdown of the core sales motions practitioners can audit and improve.

quotes.topic_title: Sahil’s sales career and Bravado overview
quotes.text: I started selling in September of 2008 was my first month with a quota. So I started selling in the middle of the last financial crisis.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Establishes direct experience selling with a quota during a major downturn—relevant credibility for recession playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Sahil’s sales career and Bravado overview
quotes.text: In that year, in 2009, I broke the company record for the most sales by any individual person in one year in the history of the company.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A specific performance example showing outlier results are possible even when the broader business is contracting.

quotes.topic_title: Sahil’s sales career and Bravado overview
quotes.text: So it's a network that purely focuses on sales, and much akin to your business, I suppose, marries community learning, upskilling, recruiting as this one place that a salesperson can go in order to beat the odds, be successful in their career, find a great job, or hit and crush quota in their role.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A clear “one-stop” model for sales career success that combines learning, hiring, and peer support into a single system.

quotes.topic_title: Bravado War Room and real-time market pulse
quotes.text: So if you're familiar with Stack Overflow and what that network and community means to engineering, Bravado has a product that's affectionately known as the War Room, which does the same thing.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Introduces a clear mental model for Bravado’s War Room by mapping it to a well-known community-driven problem-solving platform.

quotes.topic_title: Bravado War Room and real-time market pulse
quotes.text: So you have 50,000 companies, sales teams that are on Bravado. We get a realtime pulse of which companies are hitting quota, which ones are missing quota, which sales reps are closing deals with which organizations, which industries are doing better or worse.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Provides a concrete scale/data point and explains how real-time community activity can be used as market intelligence for sales performance.

quotes.topic_title: Bravado War Room and real-time market pulse
quotes.text: So we do get a really interesting perspective within the world of B2B tech sales, to be clear, a really interesting perspective on what's happening in terms of companies and revenue and forecast and quota, which gives us hopefully an opportunity to serve those members and the general tech community at large in terms of how they can beat the odds, especially as we're back to that 2008 crunch that we saw then as well.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Connects real-time quota/forecast visibility to helping teams “beat the odds” during recession-like conditions, framing the product as a recession playbook engine.

quotes.topic_title: Bravado War Room and real-time market pulse
quotes.text: But you had this great suggestion that we instead focus more specifically on what founders should change in the coming year knowing the conditions of the market and how things are turbulent and how people are spending less and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical pivot: prioritize founder-level sales process changes tailored to downturn conditions rather than generic sales improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Bravado War Room and real-time market pulse
quotes.text: So we're going to talk about five things that you can do right now to change the way your sales process works starting now for the next year.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets up an immediately actionable methodology (five concrete changes) aimed at rapid implementation with a team.

quotes.topic_title: Why sales strategy must change in downturns
quotes.text: the way in which you sell has to be different based on market condition.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A simple guiding principle: sales tactics should adapt to macro conditions rather than staying static.

quotes.topic_title: Why sales strategy must change in downturns
quotes.text: I think that today, the market has shifted because we know that the cost of capital has gone up. We know that funding has dried up. We know that investors today are only interested in companies that have strong unit economics and have high retention rates.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Explains the underlying economic drivers forcing a shift from growth-at-all-costs to efficiency and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Why sales strategy must change in downturns
quotes.text: Cold prospecting goes down in favor of cross-selling and upselling your existing customer base because it's hard to break into new accounts when companies have budget freezes and hiring freezes and layoffs, and everyone is watching really closely the capital outflow of their business.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Actionable downturn playbook: prioritize expansion revenue from existing customers when new-logo acquisition gets harder.

quotes.topic_title: Why sales strategy must change in downturns
quotes.text: So your sale strategy has to fundamentally change in order to meet the moment and meet the market to where it is.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A memorable mandate to redesign sales strategy around current buyer constraints rather than past-market assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Quota attainment data and forecasting approach
quotes.text: So in Q3 of this year, so I guess as of last month, in Q3 of this year, 63% of sales reps missed quota, 63%. That's up from 54% in Q2 and 46% in Q1.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A stark data point showing how quickly quota attainment deteriorated quarter-over-quarter, grounding forecasting decisions in reality.

quotes.topic_title: Quota attainment data and forecasting approach
quotes.text: If you broaden that out to a team wide structure, 76% of companies missed their Q3 target. 76% of companies missed their Q3 target. That's up from 59% in Q2 and 51% in Q1.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Extends the quota-miss trend from individual reps to entire companies, signaling systemic forecasting risk.

quotes.topic_title: Quota attainment data and forecasting approach
quotes.text: So the way I think about setting up a plan when you have limited visibility and some major headwinds is setting up a really conservative plan and then having milestones, short term  milestones that unlock the ability to lean into growth and spend based on hitting those targets.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A practical planning framework: conservative baseline plus predefined milestone-based “unlock” triggers for spend and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Quota attainment data and forecasting approach
quotes.text: Forecasting, you can't just forecast a quarter out every time. Obviously that's a tough way to run a business. So you got to forecast a year, but then set milestones, checkpoints and kind of make predetermined decisions that allow you to avoid the bias of then walking into Q1 and being like, "Oh, we missed in Q1, but no, no, we're really going to hit it in Q2."
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A methodology for reforecasting without thrash: annual plan + checkpoints + pre-committed decisions to prevent wishful thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Quota attainment data and forecasting approach
quotes.text: You got to set the targets upfront because as founders, we tend to have a bias towards optimism. That's generally how founders operate. In today's market, that's more of a disadvantage than an advantage.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that founder optimism can become a liability in downturns, motivating pre-commitment and conservative planning.

quotes.topic_title: Uncertainty, recession comparisons, and being wrong often
quotes.text: People try to analogize it to COVID, but I think that that's actually not a good analog for this.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Challenges the common comparison to COVID and sets up a more accurate way to reason about the current downturn.

quotes.topic_title: Uncertainty, recession comparisons, and being wrong often
quotes.text: The reason why is because COVID was an external factor versus this is actually an internal issue, which is to say that there are actually industries that are doing much better these days except for tech.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Provides a mental model for diagnosing the downturn: external shock vs sector-specific/internal dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Uncertainty, recession comparisons, and being wrong often
quotes.text: But it's really kind of tech, right? So when you see a slowdown in tech that is disproportionate, you have to assume that it may last for a much longer period of time than you imagine.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Actionable planning implication: treat a tech-specific slowdown as potentially longer-lasting and plan accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Uncertainty, recession comparisons, and being wrong often
quotes.text: I think that the only response to which is to try to get really comfortable with being wrong and adding new data in in order to make decisions regularly without the fear of coming across as not knowing what you're doing.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A practical operating principle for volatile environments: normalize frequent reforecasting and decision updates without stigma.

quotes.topic_title: How Bravado collects quota benchmarks
quotes.text: Yeah, exactly. That's right. It's a gift to get model.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Introduces Bravado’s core exchange mechanism for collecting data while delivering value back to participants.

quotes.topic_title: How Bravado collects quota benchmarks
quotes.text: So the way it works is that you enter your stats, and in doing so, you get global benchmarks of how you're doing versus other reps or other companies.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Actionable model: incentivize data contribution by immediately returning personalized benchmarking value.

quotes.topic_title: How Bravado collects quota benchmarks
quotes.text: So there's a premium for being accurate here because otherwise you don't actually get a real sense of how you're doing versus others. So there's an incentive structure that's built in to be really precise.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Highlights a built-in quality-control mechanism: accuracy is self-reinforced because bad inputs reduce the usefulness of the output.

quotes.topic_title: How Bravado collects quota benchmarks
quotes.text: Then that information feeds into our kind of global leaderboard where we are able to slice and dice and say, "Okay, of companies that are headquartered in San Francisco, here's how your company's doing. Of sales reps that sell to CMOs, here's how you're doing. Of reps who carried a quota of between 500, 700K this quarter, here's how you rank."
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Concrete example of segmentation-based benchmarking that makes the data more relevant and comparable for practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: How Bravado collects quota benchmarks
quotes.text: Simple, everything's available for free. Just come to bravado.co and we have something called a Seller Portfolio. Go ahead and build one of those and then enter the information and then you'll start to receive the stats as they come out each quarter.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Clear call-to-action describing the exact steps to participate and receive quarterly benchmark outputs.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking sales comp plans for retention
quotes.text: Again, I'm going to use the most common examples for this, and every combines different, et cetera, but what's really common is if you have a 200K OTE, 100K base, 100K commission, then your quota will be $1 million. So the ratio between your OTE and your quota is typically five to one. So your quota is usually 5X. This comes from this idea that your cost for a sales rep fully loaded should be about 20% so you can afford to pay 20% of your salary to a sales rep.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Gives a concrete SaaS comp math model (OTE-to-quota ratio) and the underlying cost-of-sales assumption teams can sanity-check.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking sales comp plans for retention
quotes.text: Then six months ago, all of a sudden the music stopped and capital got expensive and everybody started being like, "Whoa, wait a minute. We should think about things like net dollar retention and we should think about what renewal rates look like and we should think about how efficient you are at acquiring customers."
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Reframes what “good” looks like in a downturn—shifting the operating metrics comp plans should reinforce.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking sales comp plans for retention
quotes.text: So let's go back to our example. So team player player A who closed 15 deals for 1.5 million, poster child for the company, got $400,000. Let's say out of their 15 customers, 10 of them churn next year and only five of them actually end up renewing. How much does that affect player A's compensation, their performance, their celebration, et cetera? Doesn't affect them at all. Make no difference. 99% of SaaS companies are set up this way, right?
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Highlights the core misalignment: most SaaS orgs reward bookings even when those customers churn, creating perverse incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking sales comp plans for retention
quotes.text: What we haven't done is built a modern technical sales compensation plan that actually aligns the needs and incentives of the business, the customer and the rep.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Provides a clear design principle practitioners can use to evaluate or redesign comp plans around retention and customer outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why comp plans don’t innovate and short-termism
quotes.text: So companies tend to weigh down comp plans with basically a bunch of bullshit that doesn't have anything to do with how the compensation plan should be structured, but just has to do with the whims of the executives and the board that month or that quarter.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Highlights a practical failure mode: comp plans get distorted by short-term executive priorities rather than durable incentive design.

quotes.topic_title: Why comp plans don’t innovate and short-termism
quotes.text: But I would say that in today's economy, taking a longer term view to a sales compensation, instead the short term, like you're a hunter, your job is just to close deals and doesn't really matter, a dollar is a dollar no matter where it comes from is not true anymore.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Actionable shift in comp philosophy: not all revenue is equal, so incentives should account for long-term outcomes like retention and quality of deals.

quotes.topic_title: Why comp plans don’t innovate and short-termism
quotes.text: Sales is one of the least diverse professions when it comes to leadership and it's one of the things that we really champion here at Bravado is this idea that 92% of sales leaders or VPs of sales are white.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point tied to a broader argument about copy-paste leadership and lack of innovation in sales org design.

quotes.topic_title: Why comp plans don’t innovate and short-termism
quotes.text: If I offered you a plan that said, hey, you can grow by 20% revenue quarter over quarter or we can spike revenue by 75% this quarter though I don't know what that's going to do to the business in the future. Which of these do you want?
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A memorable decision framing that exposes founders’ bias toward short-term spikes over compounding, durable growth.

quotes.topic_title: Why comp plans don’t innovate and short-termism
quotes.text: But at the end of the day, there is no replacement for building a product that customers love and having a great go to market motion that brings that product and that value to your clients and ensuring that they actually are thrilled that they bought your product and are getting a lot of value from it.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Re-centers the comp-plan debate on the underlying operating principle: durable growth comes from customer value, not incentive hacks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Creating a product, especially one that your users can't live without is damn hard. But it's made easier by working closely with your colleagues to capture ideas, get feedback, and being able to iterate quickly.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product-building approach: tight collaboration loops to speed up iteration and quality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Miro, you can build out your product strategy by brainstorming with sticky notes, comments, live reactions, voting tools, even a timer to keep your team on track.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, tool-supported workflow for structuring product strategy sessions and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can also bring your whole distributed team together around wire frames where anyone can draw their own ideas with a pen tool or put their own images or mock-ups right into the Miro board.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for enabling inclusive, real-time collaboration in distributed product/design work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With one of Miro's ready-made templates, you can go from discovery and research to product roadmaps to customer journey flows to final mocks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers an end-to-end process model for moving from research to execution artifacts using templates.

quotes.topic_title: Retention-first: shift top sellers to customer success
quotes.text: Let's start here, which is cold call, cold email response rates have never been lower. Never been lower.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Sets the macro premise that outbound is materially less effective, motivating a retention-first strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Retention-first: shift top sellers to customer success
quotes.text: In conversations with them, they've been really clear that they're seeing this incredible, the average enterprise sales cycle is 62 days, it's now like 115 days or something.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point illustrating how buying decisions are slowing, impacting revenue predictability.

quotes.topic_title: Retention-first: shift top sellers to customer success
quotes.text: So in a world in which you can't sell to new customers, your only hope is to keep the ones you got for long enough to survive and then hopefully even maybe be able to upsell and cross-sell those customers into new products, as well as potentially leverage those customers to get warm intros into a potential new business.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Offers an actionable recession playbook: retain, expand, and use existing customers as a source of warm pipeline.

quotes.topic_title: Retention-first: shift top sellers to customer success
quotes.text: Take your best sales people and make them CSMs. There's no point. There's no point in having your best salespeople sell.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A contrarian org-design move: redeploy top closers to prevent churn when new-logo selling stalls.

quotes.topic_title: Retention-first: shift top sellers to customer success
quotes.text: But I can tell you it's what we're doing. I can tell you I'm actually doing it. We're taking our best people and are moving them into CSM at Bravado.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Grounds the advice in a real example, signaling conviction and practical applicability.

quotes.topic_title: Become a value-added advisor with customer benchmarks
quotes.text: Because the advantage you have as a vendor, this is advantage we have in sales as Bravado, but it's the advantage that every vendor has is you get a cross=section of what everyone who fits a certain ICP is doing at the same time.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Highlights a vendor-specific leverage point—aggregated visibility across similar customers—that can be turned into differentiated customer value.

quotes.topic_title: Become a value-added advisor with customer benchmarks
quotes.text: How good are you at extracting value out of that and finding ways of becoming less of a tool as part of the SaaS stack and more of a value added advisor that can help you actually plan and prepare for what to do next.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A reframing from “software tool” to “advisor” that pushes teams to operationalize insights, not just ship features.

quotes.topic_title: Become a value-added advisor with customer benchmarks
quotes.text: They put out a white paper for lead gen. I want to put out a white paper for customer retention.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: Counterintuitive content strategy shift: use thought leadership to keep customers during downturns, not just acquire new ones.

quotes.topic_title: Become a value-added advisor with customer benchmarks
quotes.text: One thing that we're actually doing is we're basically saying to all of our clients, "Hey, we'll tell you what percentage of companies that look like you are hiring or not hiring. I'll tell you how they're adjusting quotas. I'll tell you how they are changing their comp plans. I'll tell you how much they're paying. I'll tell you what percentage of their sales teams' hitting quota, et cetera, if you stick around with us as a client."
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A concrete retention playbook: package proprietary benchmarks (hiring, quotas, comp, attainment) as an ongoing client benefit.

quotes.topic_title: Become a value-added advisor with customer benchmarks
quotes.text: But if they're getting insights on what's happening in the market, that's still valuable. That's still something that they can't get elsewhere that I am uniquely positioned to offer to my customer base.
quotes.speaker: Sahil Mansuri
quotes.context: A practical recession tactic: when core demand slows, preserve value by delivering unique market intelligence customers can’t source elsewhere.
